title: Full Time : World Cup group stage recap
body_text:
Start every morning of the 2023 World Cup with Full Time passed directly to your inbox. Sign up here.
After a quick â€œrest day,â€ I think I finally know what an F1 pit stop feels like. Iâ€™m Emily Olsen, here with Meg Linehan and Steph Yang â€” welcome to Full Time!
Rest Day
Get caught up on the â€˜underdogsâ€™
Obviously, this newsletter has a strong American influence, but I think we all need a break, and this rest day has come at the perfect time. There are so many other great stories I want to highlight before that U.S. game against Sweden (there is still plenty of time to talk about that one).
Advertisement
Parity has become a key feature in this expanded World Cup. Lopsided scores were also met with surprising victories â€” some of which came from first-time participants. More countries are investing in the womenâ€™s game and itâ€™s showing: hello, Morocco, and, of course for a while now, the Netherlands. Meanwhile, other teams are winning despite their federations â€” taking a page from the USWNT handbook.
These results havenâ€™t been freak accidents, but well-practiced and prepared performances that happened while you werenâ€™t watching. So, itâ€™s not their fault if youâ€™re caught by surprise, but it is our job to fill you inâ€¦
Tamerra Griffin looked at Nigeria and where its round of 16 ticket came from:
- Despite fumbling their last international competition at the Womenâ€™s Africa Cup of Nations, the team has been steadily building ever since.
- Unbeaten in their group-stage matches, against teams ranked significantly higher than them, they finished second in their group behind Australia.
- Their players are with clubs like Racing Louisville, Wuhan Chegu Jianghan in the Chinese Womenâ€™s Super League and beyond. Then thereâ€™s Barcelonaâ€™s Asisat Oshoala, who became the first African woman to win a Champions League title in 2021 before adding a second last season.
â€œLetâ€™s not get lost in the respectability politics of glitzy club teams and individual awards,â€ Tamerra says, â€œNigeria can ball, period, and theyâ€™ve shown tens of thousands of fans not only what they are capable of, but what they can do against rankingsâ€™ odds.â€
Jamaica and South Africa, like Nigeria, have had to play this game with the backdrop of a federation that is unresponsive at best, and harmful at worst. As Nick Miller writes, â€œIf thereâ€™s a message for the national federations of those three countries itâ€™s this: donâ€™t you dare try taking credit for their success.â€
- What else? Nigeria, Jamaica and South Africaâ€™s success owes nothing to those who failed them
- And also: Zambiaâ€™s heroes and a â€˜sorrowfulâ€™ tale of coercion allegations, vulnerability, and pain
Appreciating Sinc and Marta
This World Cup is likely the last for Canadian great Christine Sinclair and definitely Brazilian legend Marta, both of whom went out in heartbreaking group-stage defeats.
I canâ€™t say goodbye to Sinc â€” who faced Australia in her 23rd World Cup start, putting her next to Joy Fawcett for second most in World Cup history â€” any better than Steph Yang: â€œItâ€™s inevitable and reasonable, and a reminder that no good thing lasts forever. All we have are the games that we get and then one day even those will be a memory thatâ€™s burrowed its way into our hearts for safekeeping, slowly growing duller in detail as memories lose their crisp edge. What will remain is that feeling, the love and awe and joy and misery of the moment.â€
This speech from Marta about how far womenâ€™s sports have come during her lifetime ğŸ¥º pic.twitter.com/fpqCNJ7Rs3
â€” Bri Lewerke (@brilewerke) August 2, 2023
â€œContinue supporting womenâ€™s football,â€ Marta said. She called time on her own World Cup appearances and pointed out that even though it was her last, it wasnâ€™t for her teammates.
Next up, Meg Linehan shares her thoughts on the first half of the tournament belowâ€¦
Megâ€™s Corner
The best World Cup yet
We are only just about to start the knockout stage, but it already feels pretty fair to say this is the best World Cup weâ€™ve ever seen.
Advertisement
For all of the anxiety about expanding to 32 teams, the way that the group stage played out has not only reinforced that we were ready to move to 32 teams, but has made the tournament so much better.
So itâ€™s really hard for me to pick one standout moment from this tournament so far.
On Thursday, I think I had the perfect kind of encapsulation of bouncing back and forth between watching Morocco leading Colombia and Germany trying to find a winning goal against South Korea, then trying to focus on Morocco waiting for the result from that Germany game.
That, to me, is just a wild and perfect World Cup sequence.
And obviously, there was Germany going out. They were a lot of peopleâ€™s favorites to win the whole thing. Itâ€™s just been so unpredictable in the best possible way.
What is the fan experience like?
I went through the fan fest here in Sydney and not only did I watch a tuba band from Australia play strange covers of American pop music, I watched two guys come in and absolutely lose their minds posing for photos next to Linda Caicedoâ€™s jersey.
Sometimes you just have to marvel at watching an Australian Oompa Loompa band play Bon Jovi on the other side of the World. Thatâ€™s a #FIFAWWC moment, baby. pic.twitter.com/2ChVBunN4h
â€” Meg Linehan (@itsmeglinehan) August 3, 2023
Obviously, there were a ton of Colombian fans out to watch the two Group H matches, but it feels like we have finally gotten to where itâ€™s not â€œwomenâ€™s football,â€ itâ€™s just football for these athletes.
Itâ€™s â€justâ€ the World Cup.
There are so many standout players from this tournament, but if I think of a breakout star of this year in general, I think it has to be both Linda Caicedo and the pure, wonderful chaos.
No result can be taken for granted and it has made for a really amazing tournament to this point.

Remembering the Group Stage
Group stage Best XI
Itâ€™s worth commemorating the accomplishments of players to this point, regardless of how this tournament finishes. Best XIs can so easily skew toward how a playerâ€™s team fared when thereâ€™s only a maximum of seven games for any one team to play. Why not sort out who was the standout of group play (hint: itâ€™s Linda Caicedo) and find those diamonds among the eliminated sides who may soon be overshadowed by whoever makes a run to the final? A group of writers and editors covering the tournament for The Athletic cast their ballots; hereâ€™s who stood out in the 2023 World Cup group stage:
- Goalkeeper: Rebecca Spencer (Jamaica)
- Defenders: Ona Batlle (Spain), Julie Ertz (U.S.), Katie McCabe (Republic of Ireland), Steph Catley (Australia)
- Midfielders: Kyra Cooney-Cross (Australia), Jill Roord (Netherlands), Teresa Abelleira (Spain)
- Forwards: Linda Caicedo (Colombia), Mina Tanaka (Japan), Ary Borges (Brazil)
â€“ Jeff Rueter
Ed. note from Emily: I think itâ€™s a farce that Thembi Kgatlana isnâ€™t in this. She might be in my finalists for group-stage MVP.
Fun Time World Cup Trivia
Test your nickname knowledge
If you donâ€™t want the answer to yesterdayâ€™s question, stop scrolling nowâ€¦.
No. 72 Morocco advanced to the round of 16, becoming the lowest-ranked team to do so. They beat the record set by No. 54 South Africa who qualified a day prior.
Todayâ€™s questionâ€¦
I agree with Rebecca Lowe and Brendan Hunt, The USWNT needs a cool nickname. What is the nickname of the China womenâ€™s national team (hint: itâ€™s one of the coolest out there)?
Full-Time First Looks
The first time Yamila Rodriguezâ€™s head popped out of the dugout during Argentinaâ€™s game, her light-blue-tinted hair was visible in the stands. An Argentinian fan sitting near Laia Cervello Herrero exclaimed: â€œLook at her, that one is the anti-Messi.â€ The story of the Argentine top scorer with a, gasp, Cristiano Ronaldo tattoo.
For Ona Batlle, one of the stars of last seasonâ€™s Womenâ€™s Super League campaign, the summer involves not only the World Cup but the move of a lifetime. The former Manchester United defender is off to Barcelona Femeni. Before the World Cup, she took The Athletic through some of the crucial plays over her career.
Advertisement
Finally, you must see Jamaica coach Lorne Donaldsonâ€™s celebration as it became clear his side was going through to the next round. I donâ€™t think Iâ€™d act any differently.
